item.title: Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 534) to amend title 18, United States Code, to prohibit human cloning.

GENERAL DEBATE - The Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of general debate on H.R. 534.
The Speaker designated the Honorable John E. Sweeney to act as Chairman of the Committee.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 105 and Rule XXIII.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 534 with 1 hour of general debate. Previous question shall be considered as ordered without intervening motions except motion to recommit with or without instructions. Measure will be considered read. Specified amendments are in order.

item.title: H.R. 534, Human Cloning Prohibition Act of 2003
item.description: Cost estimate for the bill as ordered reported by the House Committee on the Judiciary on February 12, 2003

item.title: H.R. 534, Human Cloning Prohibition Act of 2003
item.description: Cost estimate for the bill as ordered reported by the House Committee on the Judiciary on February 12, 2003

summary.text:
Human Cloning Prohibition Act of 2003 - Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit any person or entity, in or affecting interstate commerce, from knowingly: (1) performing or attempting to perform human cloning; (2) participating in such an attempt; (3) shipping or receiving an embryo produced by human cloning or any product derived from such embryo; or (4) importing such an embryo or derived product.

Sets forth criminal and civil penalties.

Provides that nothing in this Act restricts areas of scientific research not specifically prohibited above, including research in the use of nuclear transfer or other cloning techniques to produce molecules, DNA, cells other than human embryos, tissues, organs, plants, or animals other than humans.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced in the House on February 5, 2003. The summary of that version is repeated here.)

Human Cloning Prohibition Act of 2003 - Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit any person or entity, in or affecting interstate commerce, from knowingly: (1) performing or attempting to perform human cloning; (2) participating in such an attempt; (3) shipping or receiving an embryo produced by human cloning or any product derived from such embryo; or (4) importing such an embryo or derived product.

Sets forth criminal and civil penalties.

Provides that nothing in this Act restricts areas of scientific research not specifically prohibited above, including research in the use of nuclear transfer or other cloning techniques to produce molecules, DNA, cells other than human embryos, tissues, organs, plants, or animals other than humans.

Human Cloning Prohibition Act of 2003 - Amends the Federal criminal code to prohibit any person or entity, in or affecting interstate commerce, from knowingly: (1) performing or attempting to perform human cloning; (2) participating in such an attempt; (3) shipping or receiving an embryo produced by human cloning or any product derived from such embryo; or (4) importing such an embryo or derived product.

Sets forth criminal and civil penalties.

Provides that nothing in this Act restricts areas of scientific research not specifically prohibited above, including research in the use of nuclear transfer or other cloning techniques to produce molecules, DNA, cells other than human embryos, tissues, organs, plants, or animals other than humans.

Directs the General Accounting Office to study and report to Congress on the need for amending such prohibition. Requires the study to include: (1) a discussion of related developments in medical technology, the need for somatic cell nuclear transfer to produce medical advances, current public attitudes and prevailing ethical views, and potential legal implications of research in somatic cell nuclear transfer; and (2) a review of any technological developments that may require that technical changes be made to such prohibition.

item.title: To amend title 18, United States Code, to prohibit human cloning.

item.titleType: Short Titles as Reported to House
item.title: Human Cloning Prohibition Act of 2003

amendment.description: Amendment in the nature of a substitute sought to prohibit human somatic cell nuclear transfer technology to initiate a pregnancy and allow its use for medical research.
amendment.purpose: Amendment in the nature of a substitute numbered 3 and printed in House Report 108-21.

latestAction.text: On agreeing to the Greenwood amendment (A002) Failed by recorded vote: 174 - 231, 1 Present (Roll no. 37).

Roll call votes on amendments in House
House amendment not agreed to: On agreeing to the Greenwood amendment (A002) Failed by recorded vote: 174 - 231, 1 Present (Roll no. 37).
House amendment offered

amendment.description: Amendment, as modified, requires the General Accounting Office, after consultation with the National Academy of Sciences, to conduct a study to assess the need (if any) for amendment of the prohibition on human cloning contained in the bill.
amendment.purpose: Amendment numbered 1 and printed in House Report 108-21. Provides for a study by the General Accounting Office (GAO) to assess the need (if any) for amendment of the prohibition on human cloning. GAO must report its finding to Congress within 2 years.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
